Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: QoS Assured Multimedia Communication over Non-stationary Wireless Channels

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The next-generation wireless networks are targeted at supporting various applications such as voice, data, and multimedia. However, wireless channels are unreliable and the capacity of a wireless fading channel is time-varying, which may cause severe degradation to video/audio quality. Therefore, it is particularly challenging to design quality of service (QoS) assurance mechanisms and multimedia compression techniques for multimedia communication over wireless networks. This project aims to develop new theories and techniques for QoS assured multimedia communication over non-stationary wireless channels. To accomplish this goal, the following research tasks are conducted: 1) developing a novel evolutionary spectrum approach, which is able to accurately model the dynamics of general non-stationary fading channels; 2) developing QoS-assured sliding-mode congestion control and scheduling mechanisms for multimedia communication over non-stationary fading channels; and 3) developing gamma rate theory for causal rate control in source coding, and developing cross layer design to achieve both network friendliness and viewer friendliness for multimedia coding and transmission. Techniques developed in this project will fill some important gaps in fundamental understanding of QoS-assured multimedia communication over non-stationary wireless channels, and provide the theoretical underpinning for system design and algorithm implementation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The next-generation wireless networks are targeted at supporting various applications such as voice, data, and multimedia over packet-switched networks. A main goal of these networks is providing quality of service (QoS) for inelastic traffic from applications such as voice-over-IP, interactive video, mobile TV, and interactive gaming, while achieving high data rate for elastic traffic, e.g, email, file transfer, and web traffic. However, wireless channels are unreliable and the capacity of a wireless fading channel is time-varying, which may cause severe degradation to video/audio quality. Therefore, it is particularly challenging to design QoS assurance mechanisms and multimedia compression techniques for multimedia communication over wireless networks.

 

To address the challenge, this project is intended to develop new theories and techniques for QoS assured multimedia communication over non-stationary wireless channels. To accomplish this, the following research tasks have been conducted: 1) developed a novel evolutionary spectrum (ES) approach, which is able to accurately model the dynamics of general non-stationary fading channels, 2) developed QoS assured sliding-mode congestion control & scheduling mechanisms for multimedia communication over non-stationary fading channels, 3) developed gamma rate theory for causal rate control in source coding, and developed cross layer design to achieve both network friendliness and viewer friendliness for multimedia coding and transmission, and 4) developed a general-purpose testbed with implementation of the proposed algorithms.

 

The approaches developed by the project team are expected to fill some important gaps in fundamental understanding of QoS-assured multimedia communication over non-stationary wireless channels, and provide the theoretical underpinning for system design and algorithm implementation. The developed Evolutionary Spectrum approach not only results in new theoretic fading channel models, but also provides new channel simulators for popular network simulators such as NS-2/3, OPNET, and QualNet, with an unprecedented capability of simulating fading channels for mobile terminals with time varying velocities. The developed Sliding Mode control approach provides simple, optimal, and scalable solution to the general problem of joint congestion control and scheduling with multiple classes of QoS; moreover, it also provides a new family of QoS-assured congestion control mechanisms that are robust against link failures. The gamma rate theory represents the first theoretical study on the tradeoff between network friendliness and viewer-friendliness of video coding.

 

The research has attracted interest from industry, and may have impact on development of products such as cell phones, tablets, laptop, and wireless routers, in providing real-time multimedia service over wireless networks. The integrated research and education program has helped train wireless and multimedia engineers to cope with challenges of their future careers. Furthermore, the PI has used this project to inspire the learning processes and the discovery interests of the general public and students of all ages.
